If it does (and that’s a stretch) it has no significance. The Bible mentions Romans. We’re pretty sure Romans did exist in Biblical times. But that does not mean the Bible is a primary resource for archaeologists. Similarly the Bible is not an authority on cosmology even if one passage in one translation can (with a huge amount of wishful thinking) be interpreted as a vague agreement with an oversimplification of current science. Before the Big Bang Theory was hypothesised, how many biblical scholars were proposing that cosmology? None (as far as I know). Even Abbe Lemaître based it on science, not the Bible. If the Steady State Theory had won out, there would no doubt be some convoluted explanation of how that agrees with some other Biblical phrase, or even the same one. Actually it does match SST better than BBT - the “creating new earth” could be creating new matter. So, it looks like the Bible agrees with a failed cosmology. Which is pretty much in line with its reliability on archaeology.
